elements.text: PART ONE
[OC]: Deral, what's happening? Your signal keeps fading in and out. Deral?
I'm almost there. I'm only five, maybe six, spans away.
[OC]: I'm registering activity in the level below you.

You're too late. Fraxin, I'm there. I made it. There's a, a structure ahead. Could be living quarters of some kind. These caverns are so damned dark it's hard to be sure of anything. I'm going to take a closer look on foot.
[OC]: (sotto) I see you. Watch your back. Come back to us safely, my sweet, sweet love.
Footsteps.
Lieutenant Deral. Lieutenant Shayru Deral.
[OC]: What's happening?
I can hear him, Fraxin.
You've done very well, Lieutenant, to come this far.
Koth, show yourself.
As you wish.
Footsteps approach.
I'm sorry, Major, but you know why I'm here.
Energy weapons fire.
Are you finished?
Did you really think it would be that simple, Lieutenant? Did you?
What are you? What, what, argh!
Now, where was I?
Rewinds recording.
[OC]: Come back to us safely, my sweet, sweet love.
Sounds of insects chirping, rustle of vegetation.
Doctor, please, can we just stop? I mean, just for ten minutes. I'm hot, thirsty
And complaining again.
Thank you, C'Rizz. Some of us aren't built for the jungle, you know. I'm just mere flesh and bone. Hot, tired flesh and bone, as it happens.
Yes, you're right. She is complaining again. Design flaw with her species, I'm afraid.
She has flaws? Oh, I hadn't noticed.

Oh, very funny. It's been two days since the Kro'ka sent us trekking into this jungle. I've got bruises up and down my legs, I'm being bitten to death by insects the size of tennis balls, and all you two can do is mock me. Charming. I take it we're no nearer to finding the Tardis, then.
We're nearer. I can feel her. But how near is a good question. The old girl's doing her best, but it doesn't work like a road map.
You're tired as well, Doctor. Perhaps Charlotte's right. A rest might help us all.
Well, I suppose it wouldn't hurt.
Oh, thank heavens. And C'Rizz, again, stop calling me Charlotte.
I think we should stop here. There you are. Somewhere nice and comfy for you, Charlotte.
(sigh of relief) Look, Doctor, what exactly is going on here? I mean, one minute we're in Light City, the next we're in, well, the Amazon by the looks of it.
I wasn't aware my world had areas like this, Doctor. Although I like the damp atmosphere. Reminds me of before the Company came.
Yes, it is rather mysterious, isn't it. All these different zones sectioned off from one another. It could be a natural phenomenon. Then again
You think it could be deliberate?
The Kromon?
No, no, it would take something far more powerful than them. But without more information it's all just conjecture.
Everything's always a mystery these days. Oh, what I'd give for a straight forward uncomplicated ham sandwich right now.
Shush a moment.
What?
Shh, shh. C'Rizz, your ears are better than mine.
(sotto) Running water. Over there, I think. I can feel the moisture in the air.
Oh, I thought we were suppose to be resting.
Come on, Charley, don't dawdle. Don't you want a shower?
Oh.
Commander, I'm picking up three traces moving towards the entrance of sector four.
(female)What are they using, a skimmer?
No, they seem to be on foot. And now two more traces, maybe twenty, twenty five spans behind the first three. Looks like they've got transport, judging by their speed.
Move to amber alert. I'll tell the Major.
A waterfall.
It's beautiful. Reminds me of the J@kuls® Canyon.
Let me guess. The Eye of Orion?
Iceland, actually. I had the most wonderful mud bath there. Of course, I'm unlikely to get the chance to do so again.
Yes, well, I'd settle for an ordinary wash, if you don't mind.
Splash!
Oh, that is heavenly.
Doctor, over here.
Walks through vegetation.
What do you think this is?
The remnants of some sort of hoverskimmer, I think.
Movement of metal pieces.
Ideal transport in this kind of terrain. It's taken a bit of a fall, though. The fuel chambers must have blown, judging by the amount of debris.
Wonder what happened to its owner?
There's your answer, in the foliage.
A body.
A skeleton, more like. That's odd. These scorch marks look relatively fresh. Can't be more than a few days old. If he really was in the skimmer, the rate of decomposition has been phenomenal.
It's coated in something.
It feels like soil. It's everywhere. In the eye sockets, the mouth, all over the vertebrae.
It appears quite moist yet this ground is dry, which is odd this close to a waterfall.
You'd noticed that, did you? Good. Now let's. Hang on, there's something in his hand. A locket! Looks like he was a father.
You two! Put your hands above your head and remain still.
(female) Who are you and what are you doing here?
Us? We, er, are just tourists. You know how it is. The day job starts getting you down, the grind of the nine to five. Nothing like a week in the jungle to clear the cobwebs.
What is that?
If you're referring to me, my name is C'Rizz.
Bryn, do you recognise the species?
Never seen it before, ma'am.
We're too busy for this. Shoot them and conceal the corpses.
Wait. Wait. We really are on an expedition. We're just trying to recover some lost property.
Captain, over here. There's a body.
You two, move away slowly and keep still.
Be sensible. It's skeletal. Whatever happened occured ages ago.
Are you with Koth?
We're with no one. Look, I'm known as the Doctor, and believe it or not, my friend and I just stumbled on this ourselves. Oof!

I've lost two men to this jungle, and that pile of bones you're lying in is most likely one of them. Understand this. It's about expedience. I don't have the resources to take prisoners. If you give me the slightest resistance, I will shoot you where you stand. Am I clear?
As crystal.
(sotto) Oh, Doctor. How do you do it?
Who are they?
It's hard to tell, Commander. I'm just picking up bits with the long range scanners.
Could they be military?
Maybe, but one of them seems to be deliberately keeping out of the way of the others, like she's hiding.
Can't be another assault squad, not so soon.
Well, if they're recruits, they're certainly acting strangely.
And if they were military, they'd be more organised than this. We need more information before we act.
I'll take a team.
No, I don't want a fire fight.
But surely
Quillian, just go up on your own, stay hidden, and see what you can find out.

Captain Tysus, I appreciate how limp our story sounds to you, but think about it. Neither of us is armed, we have no communications devices to speak of, and we're carrying food supplies and tents. Do we really look like soldiers to you?
Who said anything about soldiers? All right, I'll admit neither of you really cut it as
potential mercenaries, but it's a known fact that Koth is recruiting dropouts and losers.
Thank you very much.
And who is this Koth you keep mentioning?
Somewhere in this jungle we suspect the existence of a terrorist training facility. We believe it's under the command of Major Terrian Koth, a decorated war veteran of the Ondrokkan Defence Fleet.
I've never heard of it. But then, that's not surprising. And you are here to flush him out?
Not quite.
Well, if I was your renegade Major, I wouldn't place myself out in the heat of the jungle.
Meaning?
I'd base myself underground, where scanners and sensors couldn't penetrate. Preferably next to a helpful supply of fresh water. Now look around you. What do you see?
A waterfall.
Yes, and behind it?
A cave mouth.
Isn't that where you'd go?
All right, Doctor, you've earned yourself a reprieve for the moment. Bryn, you know the drill. Set up a mobile command unit.
Yes, ma’am.
Take custody of
It's pronounced Keriz, Captain.
Whatever. Doctor, you're with me. We're going to take a closer look at those caves.
(sotto) Oh, Doctor, now where are you going?
Keep still.
(gasps) Who are you?
Don't turn around. Keep very still. You're next to a riva plant.
A what?
They're almost blind, but they do react to movement.
And then what do they do? Ow!
They sting.
Skimmer lands. Footsteps on rock.
Major Koth? Major?
Yes, Vayla. What's troubling you?
We have more intruders. Five of them, by the waterfall entrance at sector four.
And this troubles you?
The frequency of the incursions does. Sooner or later, our position here will become untenable.
You think we should leave.
I don't think it will be long before the decision will be forced upon us.
Vayla, we are almost finished. Our preparations here are nearing completion, not just in this camp, but in the others too.
You mean
We are close, so close now. Oh, you've lost so much, Vayla. All of us have. And soon, those who have wronged us, soon they will pay the full blood price.
My hand's gone numb! How poisonous are those things?
Try and keep your voice down. And the answer to your question is very.
What!
If we don't act fast, the paralysis will spread up your arm and attack your whole nervous system. You won't be able to so much as blink. Fortunately, there's a cure.
An antidote?
Not quite, but heat degrades the toxin. I can use my gun to heat up your water flask.
I'm not putting my hand in boiling water.
You are if you ever want to blink again. Besides, it's not quite boiling. Here, use this stick to bite down on. Ready?
Mmmph.
Right then.
Charley screams.
Before we go in, Captain, I found this locket on the body by the skimmer.
Click of locket opening.
Oh, that confirms it. That body, his name is Lieutenant Fraxin. Those are his children.
I am sorry.
The thing is, he and Deral, we only lost comms with them two days ago. What strips the flesh from a body at that speed?
I don't know, but perhaps the answer's down here.
You go in first. And remember I'll have a gun on you all the way.
Footsteps.
There really is no need for all this paranoia. I wish you'd argh!
Buzzing noise.
Doctor.
Something, something in my mind.
Tell your people I will address them this afternoon.
Very well, Major.
But first we must oh!
Buzzing noise.
Major? Major, are you all right?
Yes. Yes, Commander. I'm fine. (noise stops) How very interesting.
The Doctor is still suffering with the noise, then it fades.
Are you all right?
Yes. Yes, I will be. Something touched my mind. Something very powerful indeed.
Interesting. Just as we entered these caves. Some kind of defence system?
Perhaps. But it didn't affect you, and it seemed to be as surprised as I was by the connection. This Koth, does he have telepathic abilities?
No, of course not. He's Ondrokkan, just like me. Did you learn anything?
I don't know. It was a raw, intense, almost overwhelming emotion.
What kind of emotion?
Rage. Pure rage.
Back outside in the jungle.
This is Sergeant Bryn to scout ship. Do you read me?
I don't think they
Be quiet. Please respond, scout ship.
Static.
It looks like we're on our own.
I could have told you that. You see, the Doctor thinks we may
I can't understand it. We checked the communications system before we left the ship.
May I ask, what world do you think you're on now?
Setarus, of course. Why?
Just wondered. Look, is it really necessary to keep me tied up? I'm not really very good at being dangerous.
I don't think you represent too much of a threat. I just can't be bothered to keep an eye on you, that's all.
I don't understand. This Koth character. Your Captain seemed to think he was some kind of war hero.
He was one of the most venerated soldiers in our Fleet. Ever been to Ondrokkan?
Ever seen anyone like me on Ondrokkan before?

Ondrokkan is by and large a peaceful world. We have six major continents policed by a Global Defence Fleet. But over the years, as we've expanded our trading routes, so we've attracted enemies. Other worlds in this sector of space don't quite share our affluence.
Perhaps you don't share enough of it with them.
Arguably. But our enemies have found a way to hurt us. Terrorist attacks on civilians tend to turn the heads of politicians.
Terrorists.
Well armed and well equipped. And with uncomfortably accurate insights into our weaknesses.
And Koth is one of them? A double agent.

No, no, far from it. Koth was stationed in Baytara, one of the largest cities on Ondrokkan. A lot of the Defence Fleet's administration was based there. Baytara was an island. It supposedly made it more secure. But no one could have foreseen what happened.
The terrorists attacked Baytara?

There was an outbreak of Kestila sickness, a lethal disease most thought had been eliminated centuries ago. They must have grown the spores on one of the outer worlds. Trouble was, we had no natural defence for it, certainly no vaccine. Baytara was consumed within days, every single lifeform on the island wiped out.
So what's Koth's connection?
That's where he'd settled. He was on a deep space mission then, but his wife and children were there.
I don't understand. I know the military mind, Captain. Even in the face of personal tragedy a man like that would hold true to his values. Why turn renegade?

They didn't want to distract him from his mission, so they held the news back. Meanwhile the government, scared the disease might cross to the mainland, chose to atomise the island. When Koth found out, there weren't even bodies to bury.
And that's when he defected.
Not immediately. Koth denounced them publicly, eventually he disappeared, or so we thought. But he decided he could do a better job of protecting the people than the
government could.
He set up his own army?

At first we didn't take him seriously, then reports started coming in of defections. Key personnel of the type who could really make a difference fleeing, we discovered, to an unexplored world, Setarus.
And so you've been sent here, or rather, to Setarus, to find him.
Meanwhile, the terrorists continued attacking and Koth's army became an urban myth to a nervous populace. A symbol of hope. And now, well, now he could be the biggest problem of the lot.
And what will you do when you find him? It sounds like he needs help, not a laser blast through the head.
I'm a soldier, not a therapist. I have two options. Retrieve him or close him down. I've lost two men already. What would you do?
How's your hand?
Sore.
Be grateful you've still got it. Amputation would have been the next step.
You have my eternal thanks. And should you ever sit on one of those riva plants, it would give me great pleasure to return the favour.
Come on.
Where are we going?
Somewhere safe, and via a much swifter route than your friends took.
They're coming, just like I told you they would.
We must have more.
Vayla says the recruits are unhappy. I've told her we're nearing completion.
This troubles you.
No, but
It show hesitation.
2: It has no free will.
We should unmake it.
I'm sorry.
It is sorry.
The voices laugh. Lots of them.
If there is a base down here, they're dug in deep.
Have you noticed something, by the way?
No, should I?
Give me your torch. Now, look at these walls. Where do you think this half-light's coming from?
Natural luminance?
So you'd think, but look at the rock. It's not like any rock I've ever seen before. Look at it closely. And it's quite densely packed. Not a thing coming off it. Yet stand back, and there's light.
Well, there is some form of life down here. They look like Grelligs.
Grelligs?
Rodents. Well, that all but confirms it. They're indigenous to Ondrokkan. Major Koth must have had a few stowaways in his hold.
They seem very excited by something.
Distant squeaking.
Ah, that explains it.
What.
See for yourself. Another body.
Who's this, Sub-Commander?
I don't know, but she's not military.
Are you hurt?
She got stung by a riva. I had to boil out the poison.
What is this place?
This place? This place is the death of hope. It's a sunless, airless cavern of doom. It is, in short, the birthplace of the revolution. Welcome.
Janto.
I'm sorry. I'm not toeing the party line, am I. Naughty Janto.
Stop wittering and fetch a medkit. You're welcome, whoever you are.
I'm called Charley.
Once you've had your hand bandaged, we'll need to debrief you.
Give the girl a chance. Come on, Charley. These assassins of joy can interrogate you later.
Footsteps recede.
Did you learn anything about the others?
A couple of them are on the way down. We should be able to pick them up with the surveillance cameras. The others are on the surface. Two of them at least look like Ondrokkan military.
Is Doran with them?
I don't know, but the girl should he able to tell you. How's about a little quid pro quo, Vayla.
What do you mean?
Well, you spoke with the Major earlier. Care to share anything?
Still paranoid, Quillian?
Oh, I call it healthy scepticism.
There's news. I can't tell you more, but there's positive news. Right now, trust me, if Doran is here, we must help him.
It's like the body on the surface.
You mean Fraxin.
All the flesh has been stripped from it. The bones are almost polished. And then there's this soil again. It's everywhere.
Well, that doesn't mean much. These caves seem to be lined with it.
Yes, but where does it come from? Look at the ground, it's hard and dry. Just like the walls, in fact. Yet this stuff is moist, rich.
Your point being?
I don't know.
All very well, Doctor, but given what happened to Fraxin, I'm willing to bet this is Deral, my other missing officer.
If it is, I still can't account for the rate of decomposure.
Could it be some form of biological weapon?
Now there's a nasty thought.
Click of two way radio.
Sergeant Bryn, do you read me?
[OC]: (faint and static) Receiving, Captain.
Have you established comms with the scout ship?
[OC]: Say again, Captain. You're breaking up with (static)
It just gets better and better.
Near the waterfall.
Captain. Captain Tysus. This is Bryn. Do you read me?
Static.
They must be down too deep now for your signal to penetrate.
Oh, you don't say.
Sergeant Bryn, whatever left that body by the skimmer, it might still be out there.
The thought had occured to me.
There's something I haven't told you. There's someone else travelling with us. She's called Charlotte Pollard.
Why didn't you mention this before?
Because we didn't know whether you were friendly or not.
Where is she?
I don't know, but she was bathing by the waterfall when you found us.
And you expect me to leave you unguarded while I go off on this wild goose chase.
I assure you, these ropes are quite secure. Check them if you want.
If this is a trick. Oh, all right. One quick recce before nightfall might be sensible anyway.
Won't your friends be worried about you?
Oh, I'm sure. But it won't stop them getting into an even worse mess. At least, that's the way it usually works.
Janto laughs. Charley expresses pain.
I'm sorry. This isn't really my speciality.
Don't you have a doctor here?
Well, we did, but. Well, now you come to mention it, I'm not really sure. I think he got promoted or something. Tall fellow, or, no, was it a fat one? (doubtful) Yes, I'm sure we had a fat doctor.
I'll take that as a no, then. Remind me not to break any limbs while I'm down here.
Oh no, you don't want to do that.
What is this place, if it's not for medicine?
This? This is my lab. The nerve centre of the revolution, don't you know.
Oh, you're a scientist.
Used to be. But then there's a lot of us down here who used to.
Moving through foliage.
Naked female. Yeah, right. In your dreams, Bryny boy.
Gun cocks.
Who's there? Show yourself or I'll open fire. Oh. You? Stand still or I will shoot. I said, stand still!
Weapons fire. Footsteps approaching.
No! Keep back!
There's a foothold to your right. Got it? That's it. Now, jump the last bit. (thump) It would have been easier if you'd thrown your rifle down first.
I'd sooner hack a limb off.
Are you always so melodramatic? What exactly are you going to do if you find this nest of rebels, call your friend on the surface down and surround them?
Once I've got a positive sighting, we'll go back up again and I'll call in reinforcements. If Koth refuses to negotiate, I'll seal these caves permanently.
That won't be necessary. Drop the gun, and I mean drop it, because if you don't we can arrange to hack that limp off for you.
Gun dropped.
Thank you. And what about you?
Sorry, don't carry guns.
Orvik, check his pockets.
Nothing, Sub-Commander.
Well now, don't you two make a pair. Don't worry, you'll get your positive sighting soon enough. I'm sure the Major will be very keen to meet you.
[OC]: Melodramatic. What exactly are you going to do if you find this nest of rebels, call your friend on the surface
Can you see it? Can you see the universe through him?
This man, he stinks of places, of other worlds. He reeks of it.
2: He does not have fear?
We will show him fear. Show him.
2: So that we may taste it.
(many, overlapping) Show him. Show him. Taste it. Universe.
Hubbub of crowd.
So what goes on in here, then?

This? This is the main training area, where all the recruits learn how to break people's necks. Lovely stuff. You hear them in the mess, all but dribbling about how they want to help people, then they come here and Quillian shows them how to kick seven sh
Ignore him, Charley. Underneath that cynical old shell beats the heart of a rebel. Isn't that right, Janto?
Oh, Vayla, you say the sweetest things.
Quillian.
It's proving a profitable day. Two more for you.
Charley, you're all right. I was so worried. What happened to your hand?
Oh, it's nothing. Just a burn. Where's C'Rizz?
Out of trouble, I hope.
A cheer and applause.
It's the Major. He wants to make an announcement.
Hallelujah.
My friends.
It's him?
It's him.

First of all, I'd like to thank all of you for the hard work and dedication you have shown to our cause. Your daily efforts are in themselves an inspiration. But, even as we toil, so do our enemies, which is why we must remain vigilant. More positively, we continue to
attract new recruits, and today we are fortunate to welcome two more members to our extended family.
Applause.
Bryn!
Doctor, it's C'Rizz.
Yes, but something doesn't look right.
I spoke of the need for vigilance, and even as we greet new friends, our enemies continue their attempts to sabotage our plans. Quillian, bring forward the prisoners.
Footsteps.
Sergeant Bryn, please identify the woman on the left.
Her name is Tysus. She's a Captain in the Ondrokkan Defence Fleet.
Bryn.
And what are her orders?
To locate you and close down your operations here.
Please be so good as to draw your weapon. You're an expert marksman, are you not?
That's correct, sir.
Bryn, what's happened to you?
Sergeant, these people are your enemies. They are guilty of crimes against the Ondrokkan people. You are now formally given the order of execution. You will now carry out that order.
Don't listen to him. He's manipulating you.
Bryn!
Weapons fire. Thump. Cheers.
Reload your weapon.
Concentrate, man. You're being controlled.
Take aim.
Try and remember why you came here.
Fire!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
FRAXIN: [OC]: Deral, what's happening? Your signal keeps fading in and out. Deral?
DERAL: I'm almost there. I'm only five, maybe six, spans away.
FRAXIN: [OC]: I'm registering activity in the level below you.
DERAL: You're too late. Fraxin, I'm there. I made it. There's a, a structure ahead. Could be living quarters of some kind. These caverns are so damned dark it's hard to be sure of anything. I'm going to take a closer look on foot.
WOMAN: [OC]: (sotto) I see you. Watch your back. Come back to us safely, my sweet, sweet love.
KOTH: Lieutenant Deral. Lieutenant Shayru Deral.
FRAXIN: [OC]: What's happening?
DERAL: I can hear him, Fraxin.
KOTH: You've done very well, Lieutenant, to come this far.
DERAL: Koth, show yourself.
KOTH: As you wish.
DERAL: I'm sorry, Major, but you know why I'm here.
KOTH: Are you finished?
VOICE: Did you really think it would be that simple, Lieutenant? Did you?
DERAL: What are you? What, what, argh!
KOTH: Now, where was I?
WOMAN: [OC]: Come back to us safely, my sweet, sweet love.
CHARLEY: Doctor, please, can we just stop? I mean, just for ten minutes. I'm hot, thirsty
C'RIZZ: And complaining again.
CHARLEY: Thank you, C'Rizz. Some of us aren't built for the jungle, you know. I'm just mere flesh and bone. Hot, tired flesh and bone, as it happens.
DOCTOR: Yes, you're right. She is complaining again. Design flaw with her species, I'm afraid.
C'RIZZ: She has flaws? Oh, I hadn't noticed.
CHARLEY: Oh, very funny. It's been two days since the Kro'ka sent us trekking into this jungle. I've got bruises up and down my legs, I'm being bitten to death by insects the size of tennis balls, and all you two can do is mock me. Charming. I take it we're no nearer to finding the Tardis, then.
DOCTOR: We're nearer. I can feel her. But how near is a good question. The old girl's doing her best, but it doesn't work like a road map.
C'RIZZ: You're tired as well, Doctor. Perhaps Charlotte's right. A rest might help us all.
DOCTOR: Well, I suppose it wouldn't hurt.
CHARLEY: Oh, thank heavens. And C'Rizz, again, stop calling me Charlotte.
DOCTOR: I think we should stop here. There you are. Somewhere nice and comfy for you, Charlotte.
CHARLEY: (sigh of relief) Look, Doctor, what exactly is going on here? I mean, one minute we're in Light City, the next we're in, well, the Amazon by the looks of it.
C'RIZZ: I wasn't aware my world had areas like this, Doctor. Although I like the damp atmosphere. Reminds me of before the Company came.
DOCTOR: Yes, it is rather mysterious, isn't it. All these different zones sectioned off from one another. It could be a natural phenomenon. Then again
CHARLEY: You think it could be deliberate?
C'RIZZ: The Kromon?
DOCTOR: No, no, it would take something far more powerful than them. But without more information it's all just conjecture.
CHARLEY: Everything's always a mystery these days. Oh, what I'd give for a straight forward uncomplicated ham sandwich right now.
DOCTOR: Shush a moment.
CHARLEY: What?
DOCTOR: Shh, shh. C'Rizz, your ears are better than mine.
C'RIZZ: (sotto) Running water. Over there, I think. I can feel the moisture in the air.
CHARLEY: Oh, I thought we were suppose to be resting.
DOCTOR: Come on, Charley, don't dawdle. Don't you want a shower?
CHARLEY: Oh.
QUILLIAN: Commander, I'm picking up three traces moving towards the entrance of sector four.
VAYLA: (female)What are they using, a skimmer?
QUILLIAN: No, they seem to be on foot. And now two more traces, maybe twenty, twenty five spans behind the first three. Looks like they've got transport, judging by their speed.
VAYLA: Move to amber alert. I'll tell the Major.
CHARLEY: A waterfall.
DOCTOR: It's beautiful. Reminds me of the J@kuls® Canyon.
CHARLEY: Let me guess. The Eye of Orion?
DOCTOR: Iceland, actually. I had the most wonderful mud bath there. Of course, I'm unlikely to get the chance to do so again.
CHARLEY: Yes, well, I'd settle for an ordinary wash, if you don't mind.
CHARLEY: Oh, that is heavenly.
C'RIZZ: Doctor, over here.
C'RIZZ: What do you think this is?
DOCTOR: The remnants of some sort of hoverskimmer, I think.
DOCTOR: Ideal transport in this kind of terrain. It's taken a bit of a fall, though. The fuel chambers must have blown, judging by the amount of debris.
C'RIZZ: Wonder what happened to its owner?
DOCTOR: There's your answer, in the foliage.
C'RIZZ: A body.
DOCTOR: A skeleton, more like. That's odd. These scorch marks look relatively fresh. Can't be more than a few days old. If he really was in the skimmer, the rate of decomposition has been phenomenal.
C'RIZZ: It's coated in something.
DOCTOR: It feels like soil. It's everywhere. In the eye sockets, the mouth, all over the vertebrae.
C'RIZZ: It appears quite moist yet this ground is dry, which is odd this close to a waterfall.
DOCTOR: You'd noticed that, did you? Good. Now let's. Hang on, there's something in his hand. A locket! Looks like he was a father.
BRYN: You two! Put your hands above your head and remain still.
TYSUS: (female) Who are you and what are you doing here?
DOCTOR: Us? We, er, are just tourists. You know how it is. The day job starts getting you down, the grind of the nine to five. Nothing like a week in the jungle to clear the cobwebs.
TYSUS: What is that?
C'RIZZ: If you're referring to me, my name is C'Rizz.
TYSUS: Bryn, do you recognise the species?
BRYN: Never seen it before, ma'am.
TYSUS: We're too busy for this. Shoot them and conceal the corpses.
DOCTOR: Wait. Wait. We really are on an expedition. We're just trying to recover some lost property.
BRYN: Captain, over here. There's a body.
TYSUS: You two, move away slowly and keep still.
DOCTOR: Be sensible. It's skeletal. Whatever happened occured ages ago.
TYSUS: Are you with Koth?
DOCTOR: We're with no one. Look, I'm known as the Doctor, and believe it or not, my friend and I just stumbled on this ourselves. Oof!
TYSUS: I've lost two men to this jungle, and that pile of bones you're lying in is most likely one of them. Understand this. It's about expedience. I don't have the resources to take prisoners. If you give me the slightest resistance, I will shoot you where you stand. Am I clear?
DOCTOR: As crystal.
CHARLEY: (sotto) Oh, Doctor. How do you do it?
VAYLA: Who are they?
QUILLIAN: It's hard to tell, Commander. I'm just picking up bits with the long range scanners.
VAYLA: Could they be military?
QUILLIAN: Maybe, but one of them seems to be deliberately keeping out of the way of the others, like she's hiding.
VAYLA: Can't be another assault squad, not so soon.
QUILLIAN: Well, if they're recruits, they're certainly acting strangely.
VAYLA: And if they were military, they'd be more organised than this. We need more information before we act.
QUILLIAN: I'll take a team.
VAYLA: No, I don't want a fire fight.
QUILLIAN: But surely
VAYLA: Quillian, just go up on your own, stay hidden, and see what you can find out.
DOCTOR: Captain Tysus, I appreciate how limp our story sounds to you, but think about it. Neither of us is armed, we have no communications devices to speak of, and we're carrying food supplies and tents. Do we really look like soldiers to you?
TYSUS: Who said anything about soldiers? All right, I'll admit neither of you really cut it as
TYSUS: potential mercenaries, but it's a known fact that Koth is recruiting dropouts and losers.
C'RIZZ: Thank you very much.
DOCTOR: And who is this Koth you keep mentioning?
TYSUS: Somewhere in this jungle we suspect the existence of a terrorist training facility. We believe it's under the command of Major Terrian Koth, a decorated war veteran of the Ondrokkan Defence Fleet.
DOCTOR: I've never heard of it. But then, that's not surprising. And you are here to flush him out?
TYSUS: Not quite.
DOCTOR: Well, if I was your renegade Major, I wouldn't place myself out in the heat of the jungle.
TYSUS: Meaning?
DOCTOR: I'd base myself underground, where scanners and sensors couldn't penetrate. Preferably next to a helpful supply of fresh water. Now look around you. What do you see?
BRYN: A waterfall.
DOCTOR: Yes, and behind it?
TYSUS: A cave mouth.
DOCTOR: Isn't that where you'd go?
TYSUS: All right, Doctor, you've earned yourself a reprieve for the moment. Bryn, you know the drill. Set up a mobile command unit.
BRYN: Yes, ma’am.
TYSUS: Take custody of
C'RIZZ: It's pronounced Keriz, Captain.
TYSUS: Whatever. Doctor, you're with me. We're going to take a closer look at those caves.
CHARLEY: (sotto) Oh, Doctor, now where are you going?
QUILLIAN: Keep still.
CHARLEY: (gasps) Who are you?
QUILLIAN: Don't turn around. Keep very still. You're next to a riva plant.
CHARLEY: A what?
QUILLIAN: They're almost blind, but they do react to movement.
CHARLEY: And then what do they do? Ow!
QUILLIAN: They sting.
VAYLA: Major Koth? Major?
KOTH: Yes, Vayla. What's troubling you?
VAYLA: We have more intruders. Five of them, by the waterfall entrance at sector four.
KOTH: And this troubles you?
VAYLA: The frequency of the incursions does. Sooner or later, our position here will become untenable.
KOTH: You think we should leave.
VAYLA: I don't think it will be long before the decision will be forced upon us.
KOTH: Vayla, we are almost finished. Our preparations here are nearing completion, not just in this camp, but in the others too.
VAYLA: You mean
KOTH: We are close, so close now. Oh, you've lost so much, Vayla. All of us have. And soon, those who have wronged us, soon they will pay the full blood price.
CHARLEY: My hand's gone numb! How poisonous are those things?
QUILLIAN: Try and keep your voice down. And the answer to your question is very.
CHARLEY: What!
QUILLIAN: If we don't act fast, the paralysis will spread up your arm and attack your whole nervous system. You won't be able to so much as blink. Fortunately, there's a cure.
CHARLEY: An antidote?
QUILLIAN: Not quite, but heat degrades the toxin. I can use my gun to heat up your water flask.
CHARLEY: I'm not putting my hand in boiling water.
QUILLIAN: You are if you ever want to blink again. Besides, it's not quite boiling. Here, use this stick to bite down on. Ready?
CHARLEY: Mmmph.
QUILLIAN: Right then.
DOCTOR: Before we go in, Captain, I found this locket on the body by the skimmer.
TYSUS: Oh, that confirms it. That body, his name is Lieutenant Fraxin. Those are his children.
DOCTOR: I am sorry.
TYSUS: The thing is, he and Deral, we only lost comms with them two days ago. What strips the flesh from a body at that speed?
DOCTOR: I don't know, but perhaps the answer's down here.
TYSUS: You go in first. And remember I'll have a gun on you all the way.
DOCTOR: There really is no need for all this paranoia. I wish you'd argh!
TYSUS: Doctor.
DOCTOR: Something, something in my mind.
KOTH: Tell your people I will address them this afternoon.
VAYLA: Very well, Major.
KOTH: But first we must oh!
VAYLA: Major? Major, are you all right?
KOTH: Yes. Yes, Commander. I'm fine. (noise stops) How very interesting.
TYSUS: Are you all right?
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, I will be. Something touched my mind. Something very powerful indeed.
TYSUS: Interesting. Just as we entered these caves. Some kind of defence system?
DOCTOR: Perhaps. But it didn't affect you, and it seemed to be as surprised as I was by the connection. This Koth, does he have telepathic abilities?
TYSUS: No, of course not. He's Ondrokkan, just like me. Did you learn anything?
DOCTOR: I don't know. It was a raw, intense, almost overwhelming emotion.
TYSUS: What kind of emotion?
DOCTOR: Rage. Pure rage.
BRYN: This is Sergeant Bryn to scout ship. Do you read me?
C'RIZZ: I don't think they
BRYN: Be quiet. Please respond, scout ship.
BRYN: It looks like we're on our own.
C'RIZZ: I could have told you that. You see, the Doctor thinks we may
BRYN: I can't understand it. We checked the communications system before we left the ship.
C'RIZZ: May I ask, what world do you think you're on now?
BRYN: Setarus, of course. Why?
C'RIZZ: Just wondered. Look, is it really necessary to keep me tied up? I'm not really very good at being dangerous.
BRYN: I don't think you represent too much of a threat. I just can't be bothered to keep an eye on you, that's all.
C'RIZZ: I don't understand. This Koth character. Your Captain seemed to think he was some kind of war hero.
BRYN: He was one of the most venerated soldiers in our Fleet. Ever been to Ondrokkan?
C'RIZZ: Ever seen anyone like me on Ondrokkan before?
BRYN: Ondrokkan is by and large a peaceful world. We have six major continents policed by a Global Defence Fleet. But over the years, as we've expanded our trading routes, so we've attracted enemies. Other worlds in this sector of space don't quite share our affluence.
C'RIZZ: Perhaps you don't share enough of it with them.
BRYN: Arguably. But our enemies have found a way to hurt us. Terrorist attacks on civilians tend to turn the heads of politicians.
C'RIZZ: Terrorists.
BRYN: Well armed and well equipped. And with uncomfortably accurate insights into our weaknesses.
C'RIZZ: And Koth is one of them? A double agent.
BRYN: No, no, far from it. Koth was stationed in Baytara, one of the largest cities on Ondrokkan. A lot of the Defence Fleet's administration was based there. Baytara was an island. It supposedly made it more secure. But no one could have foreseen what happened.
DOCTOR: The terrorists attacked Baytara?
TYSUS: There was an outbreak of Kestila sickness, a lethal disease most thought had been eliminated centuries ago. They must have grown the spores on one of the outer worlds. Trouble was, we had no natural defence for it, certainly no vaccine. Baytara was consumed within days, every single lifeform on the island wiped out.
DOCTOR: So what's Koth's connection?
TYSUS: That's where he'd settled. He was on a deep space mission then, but his wife and children were there.
DOCTOR: I don't understand. I know the military mind, Captain. Even in the face of personal tragedy a man like that would hold true to his values. Why turn renegade?
TYSUS: They didn't want to distract him from his mission, so they held the news back. Meanwhile the government, scared the disease might cross to the mainland, chose to atomise the island. When Koth found out, there weren't even bodies to bury.
DOCTOR: And that's when he defected.
TYSUS: Not immediately. Koth denounced them publicly, eventually he disappeared, or so we thought. But he decided he could do a better job of protecting the people than the
TYSUS: government could.
DOCTOR: He set up his own army?
TYSUS: At first we didn't take him seriously, then reports started coming in of defections. Key personnel of the type who could really make a difference fleeing, we discovered, to an unexplored world, Setarus.
DOCTOR: And so you've been sent here, or rather, to Setarus, to find him.
TYSUS: Meanwhile, the terrorists continued attacking and Koth's army became an urban myth to a nervous populace. A symbol of hope. And now, well, now he could be the biggest problem of the lot.
DOCTOR: And what will you do when you find him? It sounds like he needs help, not a laser blast through the head.
TYSUS: I'm a soldier, not a therapist. I have two options. Retrieve him or close him down. I've lost two men already. What would you do?
QUILLIAN: How's your hand?
CHARLEY: Sore.
QUILLIAN: Be grateful you've still got it. Amputation would have been the next step.
CHARLEY: You have my eternal thanks. And should you ever sit on one of those riva plants, it would give me great pleasure to return the favour.
QUILLIAN: Come on.
CHARLEY: Where are we going?
QUILLIAN: Somewhere safe, and via a much swifter route than your friends took.
KOTH: They're coming, just like I told you they would.
VOICE: We must have more.
KOTH: Vayla says the recruits are unhappy. I've told her we're nearing completion.
VOICE: This troubles you.
KOTH: No, but
VOICE: It show hesitation.
VOICE: 2: It has no free will.
VOICE: We should unmake it.
KOTH: I'm sorry.
VOICE: It is sorry.
TYSUS: If there is a base down here, they're dug in deep.
DOCTOR: Have you noticed something, by the way?
TYSUS: No, should I?
DOCTOR: Give me your torch. Now, look at these walls. Where do you think this half-light's coming from?
TYSUS: Natural luminance?
DOCTOR: So you'd think, but look at the rock. It's not like any rock I've ever seen before. Look at it closely. And it's quite densely packed. Not a thing coming off it. Yet stand back, and there's light.
TYSUS: Well, there is some form of life down here. They look like Grelligs.
DOCTOR: Grelligs?
TYSUS: Rodents. Well, that all but confirms it. They're indigenous to Ondrokkan. Major Koth must have had a few stowaways in his hold.
DOCTOR: They seem very excited by something.
DOCTOR: Ah, that explains it.
TYSUS: What.
DOCTOR: See for yourself. Another body.
VAYLA: Who's this, Sub-Commander?
QUILLIAN: I don't know, but she's not military.
VAYLA: Are you hurt?
QUILLIAN: She got stung by a riva. I had to boil out the poison.
CHARLEY: What is this place?
JANTO: This place? This place is the death of hope. It's a sunless, airless cavern of doom. It is, in short, the birthplace of the revolution. Welcome.
VAYLA: Janto.
JANTO: I'm sorry. I'm not toeing the party line, am I. Naughty Janto.
VAYLA: Stop wittering and fetch a medkit. You're welcome, whoever you are.
CHARLEY: I'm called Charley.
VAYLA: Once you've had your hand bandaged, we'll need to debrief you.
JANTO: Give the girl a chance. Come on, Charley. These assassins of joy can interrogate you later.
VAYLA: Did you learn anything about the others?
QUILLIAN: A couple of them are on the way down. We should be able to pick them up with the surveillance cameras. The others are on the surface. Two of them at least look like Ondrokkan military.
VAYLA: Is Doran with them?
QUILLIAN: I don't know, but the girl should he able to tell you. How's about a little quid pro quo, Vayla.
VAYLA: What do you mean?
QUILLIAN: Well, you spoke with the Major earlier. Care to share anything?
VAYLA: Still paranoid, Quillian?
QUILLIAN: Oh, I call it healthy scepticism.
VAYLA: There's news. I can't tell you more, but there's positive news. Right now, trust me, if Doran is here, we must help him.
DOCTOR: It's like the body on the surface.
TYSUS: You mean Fraxin.
DOCTOR: All the flesh has been stripped from it. The bones are almost polished. And then there's this soil again. It's everywhere.
TYSUS: Well, that doesn't mean much. These caves seem to be lined with it.
DOCTOR: Yes, but where does it come from? Look at the ground, it's hard and dry. Just like the walls, in fact. Yet this stuff is moist, rich.
TYSUS: Your point being?
DOCTOR: I don't know.
TYSUS: All very well, Doctor, but given what happened to Fraxin, I'm willing to bet this is Deral, my other missing officer.
DOCTOR: If it is, I still can't account for the rate of decomposure.
TYSUS: Could it be some form of biological weapon?
DOCTOR: Now there's a nasty thought.
TYSUS: Sergeant Bryn, do you read me?
BRYN: [OC]: (faint and static) Receiving, Captain.
TYSUS: Have you established comms with the scout ship?
BRYN: [OC]: Say again, Captain. You're breaking up with (static)
TYSUS: It just gets better and better.
BRYN: Captain. Captain Tysus. This is Bryn. Do you read me?
C'RIZZ: They must be down too deep now for your signal to penetrate.
BRYN: Oh, you don't say.
C'RIZZ: Sergeant Bryn, whatever left that body by the skimmer, it might still be out there.
BRYN: The thought had occured to me.
C'RIZZ: There's something I haven't told you. There's someone else travelling with us. She's called Charlotte Pollard.
BRYN: Why didn't you mention this before?
C'RIZZ: Because we didn't know whether you were friendly or not.
BRYN: Where is she?
C'RIZZ: I don't know, but she was bathing by the waterfall when you found us.
BRYN: And you expect me to leave you unguarded while I go off on this wild goose chase.
C'RIZZ: I assure you, these ropes are quite secure. Check them if you want.
BRYN: If this is a trick. Oh, all right. One quick recce before nightfall might be sensible anyway.
JANTO: Won't your friends be worried about you?
CHARLEY: Oh, I'm sure. But it won't stop them getting into an even worse mess. At least, that's the way it usually works.
JANTO: I'm sorry. This isn't really my speciality.
CHARLEY: Don't you have a doctor here?
JANTO: Well, we did, but. Well, now you come to mention it, I'm not really sure. I think he got promoted or something. Tall fellow, or, no, was it a fat one? (doubtful) Yes, I'm sure we had a fat doctor.
CHARLEY: I'll take that as a no, then. Remind me not to break any limbs while I'm down here.
JANTO: Oh no, you don't want to do that.
CHARLEY: What is this place, if it's not for medicine?
JANTO: This? This is my lab. The nerve centre of the revolution, don't you know.
CHARLEY: Oh, you're a scientist.
JANTO: Used to be. But then there's a lot of us down here who used to.
BRYN: Naked female. Yeah, right. In your dreams, Bryny boy.
BRYN: Who's there? Show yourself or I'll open fire. Oh. You? Stand still or I will shoot. I said, stand still!
BRYN: No! Keep back!
DOCTOR: There's a foothold to your right. Got it? That's it. Now, jump the last bit. (thump) It would have been easier if you'd thrown your rifle down first.
TYSUS: I'd sooner hack a limb off.
DOCTOR: Are you always so melodramatic? What exactly are you going to do if you find this nest of rebels, call your friend on the surface down and surround them?
TYSUS: Once I've got a positive sighting, we'll go back up again and I'll call in reinforcements. If Koth refuses to negotiate, I'll seal these caves permanently.
QUILLIAN: That won't be necessary. Drop the gun, and I mean drop it, because if you don't we can arrange to hack that limp off for you.
QUILLIAN: Thank you. And what about you?
DOCTOR: Sorry, don't carry guns.
QUILLIAN: Orvik, check his pockets.
ORVIK: Nothing, Sub-Commander.
QUILLIAN: Well now, don't you two make a pair. Don't worry, you'll get your positive sighting soon enough. I'm sure the Major will be very keen to meet you.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Melodramatic. What exactly are you going to do if you find this nest of rebels, call your friend on the surface
KOTH: Can you see it? Can you see the universe through him?
VOICE: This man, he stinks of places, of other worlds. He reeks of it.
VOICE: 2: He does not have fear?
VOICE: We will show him fear. Show him.
VOICE: 2: So that we may taste it.
VOICES: (many, overlapping) Show him. Show him. Taste it. Universe.
CHARLEY: So what goes on in here, then?
JANTO: This? This is the main training area, where all the recruits learn how to break people's necks. Lovely stuff. You hear them in the mess, all but dribbling about how they want to help people, then they come here and Quillian shows them how to kick seven sh
VAYLA: Ignore him, Charley. Underneath that cynical old shell beats the heart of a rebel. Isn't that right, Janto?
JANTO: Oh, Vayla, you say the sweetest things.
VAYLA: Quillian.
QUILLIAN: It's proving a profitable day. Two more for you.
DOCTOR: Charley, you're all right. I was so worried. What happened to your hand?
CHARLEY: Oh, it's nothing. Just a burn. Where's C'Rizz?
DOCTOR: Out of trouble, I hope.
VAYLA: It's the Major. He wants to make an announcement.
JANTO: Hallelujah.
KOTH: My friends.
DOCTOR: It's him?
TYSUS: It's him.
KOTH: First of all, I'd like to thank all of you for the hard work and dedication you have shown to our cause. Your daily efforts are in themselves an inspiration. But, even as we toil, so do our enemies, which is why we must remain vigilant. More positively, we continue to
KOTH: attract new recruits, and today we are fortunate to welcome two more members to our extended family.
TYSUS: Bryn!
CHARLEY: Doctor, it's C'Rizz.
DOCTOR: Yes, but something doesn't look right.
KOTH: I spoke of the need for vigilance, and even as we greet new friends, our enemies continue their attempts to sabotage our plans. Quillian, bring forward the prisoners.
KOTH: Sergeant Bryn, please identify the woman on the left.
BRYN: Her name is Tysus. She's a Captain in the Ondrokkan Defence Fleet.
TYSUS: Bryn.
KOTH: And what are her orders?
BRYN: To locate you and close down your operations here.
KOTH: Please be so good as to draw your weapon. You're an expert marksman, are you not?
BRYN: That's correct, sir.
TYSUS: Bryn, what's happened to you?
KOTH: Sergeant, these people are your enemies. They are guilty of crimes against the Ondrokkan people. You are now formally given the order of execution. You will now carry out that order.
DOCTOR: Don't listen to him. He's manipulating you.
TYSUS: Bryn!
KOTH: Reload your weapon.
DOCTOR: Concentrate, man. You're being controlled.
KOTH: Take aim.
DOCTOR: Try and remember why you came here.
KOTH: Fire!

elements.text: PART TWO
Er, there was a mission.
That's it, concentrate.
Bryn, you have been given a direct order.
Major, wait. This man. I believe he is Dorin, a scientific strategist from home.
It's true, Major. We've been expecting Dorin and his aide for days now.
Has anybody actually asked him? Well? Is that what you are? A scientific strategist?
Some might say so.
Really? All right, Bryn, you can stop flapping now. Vayla. Please endeavour to authenticate our guest's identity.
Yes, sir.
But keep him and his friend under lock and key until you do. We can always reconvene if you can't.
Sir.
Keep me informed.
Footsteps recede.
It seems I owe you my life.
You're in luck. It's not every day Janto starts leaping in front of loaded guns.
Are public executions the norm around here?
No, they are not. What the hell was all that about, Vayla?
That's enough.
Don't tell me you condone it. I know you too well.
I said, enough, Janto.
I really think Bryn needs some help. I don't think he's quite himself.

He'll be looked after. But I should be more concerned about your own situation. We still have to verify your identity. And trust me, if you're not Dorin, then what happened to your friend will seem an act of mercy by comparison.
Our living quarters are a bit spartan, I'm afraid. You do sleep on a bed?
Not usually, but this will do.
Bryn, are you okay?
That woman I killed
Was a spy and an enemy agent. It's one of the Major's gifts, routing out infiltrators.
She seemed familiar.
Her name was Tysus.
Oh. It means nothing to me. But then there's you. Have we met before?
On the surface, remember?
Don't worry. New recruits often suffer a bit of disorientation. Living this far underground takes a bit of getting used to. Execution was probably asking a little bit too much too soon.
Are you with someone? That man with Tysus?
Yes, we met earlier in the jungle. By the crashed skimmer?
Like I said, it's quite natural. You'll adapt.
How long did it take you?
I can't really remember now. Your senses get affected too. Funny thing is, when we do finally leave these caves, I'll miss them. They've been a safe haven for us.
How long have you been down here?
Long enough. Meanwhile, we need to get you both settled in. I'll get Janto to give you the guided tour.
Footsteps.
We'll try and clear this up as quickly as possible. Meanwhile, I suggest you rest.
In a prison cell.
For the moment.
What exactly have I done, by the way?

As you clearly know one another, I'm hardly going to let you have the run of the camp. And I wouldn't try anything stupid. This defence screen contains energies concentrated enough to reduce you to pulp.
Footsteps recede.
Don't we even get a cup of tea?
Doctor, what happened back there?
I'm not entirely sure I Know. Only what we saw. A man coldbloodedly shoot his
commanding officer in the head.
Was he a traitor all along, then?

He might have been, but I don't think so. There was no betrayal about him, no glee, no sorrow, nothing. No emotion at all. He hardly seemed aware of what he was doing. If I had to hazard a guess, I'd say some form of mental control.
And three guesses who's responsible.
I wouldn't rush to conclusions just yet, but there's certainly something in these caves capable of exerting a telepathic influence. I felt it myself when I entered them.
Well, I didn't feel anything. But then I'm not an all-powerful Time Lord.
It's not just that. You know, I've known rebels in my time, helped overthrow the odd regime.
Show-off.
But there's a quality they've all had in common. A hunger, a desire, if you like. But that lot back there, they're different. I don't know what it is, but there's a stench about them, Charley.
What are they doing?
Practicing scenarios. Our enemies are well organised and well hidden. They're spread on many different worlds, even out in space, so we try and prepare for every possibility.
Janto, where's Bryn?
Resting. He needs a while to settle in. Perhaps asking him to put a laser bolt through someone's skull wasn't the best way of welcoming him.
All right, you've made your point.
I'm just giving C'Rizz the guided tour, Commander.
You've had no problems acclimatising, then.
None so far.
You know, I'm familiar with over forty different alien species in this region of space, and yet you are something completely new to me. Care to shed some light?
I'm Eutermesan.
And I'm the Whore Queen Babayesh. What's a Eutermesan?
What's it look like.
My patience isn't infinite, Janto. Well?
There really is no mystery. I'd be happy to sit and tell you all about my people.

Excellent. And while you're at it, perhaps you'd care to explain how and why you're here. No Ondrokkan agent that's come near to this camp has escaped to tell the tale. This location is one of the most sought after secrets in the sector, and yet here you are.
I'm not an agent of your government.
You know, there's a very simple way to establish the truth.
Vayla? You can't.
Janto, I've taken about as much insubordination from you as I'm going to today. Don't push me. Well, C'Rizz. How's about we settle this for once and for all?
I have nothing to hide.
Good. Oh, and did I mention this could be unpleasant?

Attention, attention. This is Central Command to all sectors. As of midnight tonight, food rations will be decreased by ten percent for one cycle, after which the situation will be reviewed. Your cooperation is appreciated.
Tannoy switched off.
Morale will dip.
Major. I didn't hear you come in.
But you must ensure they hold their nerve. We are so close now.

Everyone is behind you, sir. Morale will hold. But if you'll allow me, it's hard to maintain a tight infrastructure when people keep getting transferred. We lost three more last month. They went to join the others at North Camp, but we've not heard from them since. If we ran a tighter ship
You have a problem with Commander Vayla?
Some organisational issues could be better maintained.
How diligent of you, Sub-Commander. Think you could handle it better, do you?
It's just that we're not replacing the people who move on.

Then it is essential that we have new recruits. Utilise our agents in the field. The Ondrokkan people are scared and lost. They see us as their salvation. Prompt them. Encourage them to leave the planet and head towards us. Bring them to me. They are our life blood, Quillian.
Roll up your sleeve.
A truth serum?
A rather simplistic way of putting it.
Vayla, for your own sake, don't do this.
Look at him. Haven't you noticed?
What?
His colour. It's changed since he arrived. Darker, greyer.
My skin adapts to its environment. It's merely adjusting to the darkness of these caverns.
You see? You see how much we don't know?
But he's not exactly avoiding your questions. Why do this?
Because this one's different.
No, I'm not.
Why stop at him? Why not pump it into the two in the holding cells while you're at it? Think about it. Think about what you're doing.
I said I'm not different. I'm a man. I may look different, but I am simply a man with the same principles, dignity, and self-respect as any of you.
I'm sorry. I have to know. Roll up your sleeve.
Listen to him.
Is this what your army stands for? Execution and torture?
I won't ask again.
Is this what you stand for, Commander? Because I don't accept that.
Why?
Your eyes tell me so.
Big pause.
All right, C'Rizz. I'll take you at your word. But if you prove me wrong, I'll pull the trigger myself.
It's funny. You can travel all over one universe, then turn up in another, and it's still all about opening locked doors. Who says there isn't a greater pattern at work?
Sonic screwdriver whirrs.
Doctor, what are you doing?
I'm trying to get out, of course.
And then where? Into the Tardis and off we go? Only, oh yes, we've lost the Tardis.
Have we really, though? I have the strangest feeling about the old girl.
Yes, but are your strange feelings going to get us anywhere? Why don't you just accept that we're not getting out of it.
Charley, I don't fancy hanging around here until they find out they've got the wrong people. In case you hadn't noticed, they don't exactly lay on tea and fruitcake for visitors.
I'd have thought you'd be interested in helping them.
What?
These rebels. They're fighting for something they believe in.
How do you know what they're fighting for?
That man who saved you.
Janto.
He helped me with my hand. He's not a murderer. You heard what he said. He was as horrified as we were.
Trust me, Charley, there's nothing scarier than a well-meaning freedom fighter. They don't usually stop until there's
[OC]: No one left standing.
[OC]: Well, you're always so quick to judge, Mister I've Organised More Rebellions Than You've Had Hot Dinners.
[OC]: Charley, if you're developing a political consciousness, I'm absolutely delighted. I'd be happy to spend many hours debating with you, but right now I want to deactivate these defence beams.
Sonic screwdriver.
Now. Do it now.
Hang on a minute, I think I've tripped it.
Well, there's a simple way to find out.
Charley!
Footsteps.
I don't feel like a puddle of pulp, so I think you must have unlocked it.
Come on.
Footsteps.
Where to?
Just a little scout around, and then we'll try and find out where C'Rizz has got to.
Your sixth sense isn't telling you the Tardis is just round the corner, is it?
Sorry. Though oddly enough I can still feel her presence like a little voice nagging me at the back of my mind.
So what's this place for, then?
Must be the armoury, judging by the hardware. That's the other depressing reality about this universe. People can still find very efficient ways of killing each other.
It all looks a bit rusty.
Yes. Not exactly the sort of stuff you'd trust in a tight spot.
It's like scrap metal.

It's curious. The ammunition stocks seem even less well-maintained. And look at this dangerous wiring. A good way to link the various cavern levels together for lighting and communications, but it's so slap dash. Yet that defence screen was quite advanced.
There's somebody coming.
Against the wall.
I'm sure I saw someone.
Well, there's only one way he could have gone. By the way, have you noticed something about these walls?
Yes, there's a slight sting when you touch them. Makes me feel a bit sick.
Not the nicest of sensations, is it. Certainly isn't like any kind of rock I'm familiar with.
Noise.
What was that?
Our stalker, would you believe. Look.
That's just a pile of soil. It can't be. There was someone there, I'm sure of it.
Bubbling water.
Ah, beautiful, even if I say so myself.
Busy, are we, Janto?
Ah. What do you want, Quillian? It's been a hell of a day.
And you're what, cooking up a little solution to take your mind off things?
There have been a few nights when you haven't exactly said no.
Recreation is one thing, but there are people here working their arses off. And then there's you, holed up in this lab every day, quietly getting out of your skull.
Was there something you wanted?
I have news for you. The Major has authorised the extra space you were asking for. Part of Blue sector will be converted into a secondary lab.
Excellent. Thank you. Go away.
Don't suppose there's any danger of you actually doing something with it, hmm? Something productive?
Have you ever asked yourself why Koth needs a scientist? What kind of work I might just be contributing to the great cause?
I've always assumed your area was bioweaponry. I can see an elegant irony in attacking our enemies with such things.
Elegant irony. Ha! Listen to yourself. You've been down here too long.
You're not a soldier. If you were, you'd understand. This is a war. If you want to win, you have to prepare meticulously.
There's meticulous, and then there's endless. Don't you think it's odd we never hear from the other camps?
Sensible precaution, I'd have thought.
What about your friends, then? Torrin, Falma, Sula and the rest. They spent months down here. You ate with them, lived with them, drank some of this with them. Where are they now?
(sighs) They were promoted. This is the primary camp. Makes sense to spread our resources thinly.
And you don't question it.
We all lost people we cared for in Baytara. Major Koth most of all. I trust him,
even if he chooses to recruit wasters like you, Janto.
Urgh! Rats!
Lots of rodents squealing.
No. Grelligs, apparently.
Well, what's wrong with them?
I don't know, but they do seem rather agitated.
They're all moving towards those rocks.
I think it leads to the cavern below us. Here, give me a hand.
Rocks being moved.
Oh, I don't believe it. There must be thousands of them down there. Urgh, it's disgusting. Are they dead?
Not judging by the noise they're making. Hibernation, maybe? Look at the bottom of the cavern. It's lined with that soil again. They're almost burrowing into it.
But the new ones, they're like lemmings. Oh, it's horrible. They look demented.
Look into her mind. What do you see?
What is England? What is summer?
2: What are roses? What does plum pudding taste of?
Does she taste of plum pudding?
Patience. Patience.
Commander, your prisoners. They've escaped.
What!
Orvik just did a check. The defence screen's disabled and the cell's empty.
Have you got a lock on their traces?
They're the only two down here without comms badges. We've managed to isolate their patterns in auburn sector four.
Get after them, and take Bryn with you. They mustn't reach the surface. If you can't bring them back, shoot them down.
A distant alarm.
Sounds like they've noticed our absence. I suggest we get moving.
Yes, but where to?
Can you hear water?
Yes.
Come on, that might be just what we need.
Footsteps.
Well, this is more like it, Charley. A stream. If we can trace it to the surface
Doctor.
If the water flow is being channelled through that far wall
Look!
Then I think the source might. What?
The water. Look at it. Look at the colour. It's blood.
Fantastic security, Vayla. Who forgot to lock the back door, then?
Not now, Janto. Can you track their patterns?
Yes, I've got them. Ah, they've made some headway. They're just crossing into sector five now.
I heard the alarms. What happened?
The prisoners have escaped. How far behind are Quillian and Bryn?
At this pace, they should be able to intercept them before they break into the upper levels.
And if they don't?
We can't afford for them to break out. One way or another, they're not making it to the surface.
Do you still believe that I'm an infiltrator, Commander Vayla?
No. No, I don't. But I don't think you're telling me the whole truth. And your face is certainly less easy to read than Janto's.
Thanks.
But no, I'm not going to get the truth serum out again, if that's what you're worried about.
Then please trust me when I say the two people you are pursuing are not a danger to you.
(laughs) Tell me, C'Rizz. Your species. Low in numbers, are they?
Why?
You're frighteningly trusting.
I believe that Vayla is an individual of integrity.
(laughs) Terrifyingly trusting.
But you don't understand why I can be so ruthless.
I was brought up in the ways of peace, of serenity. But since meeting the Doctor and Charlotte, I've learnt to see that there's, well, more to it than that, sadly.

We all do what we must, C'Rizz. Occasionally you get to choose the journey you take. Occasionally our choices are made for us. And occasionally, we have no choice at all. My parents died in a transport crash when I was a child.
I'm sorry.

Don't be. I'm not. Not now, anyway. But my sister, Susa, I mean, I'm a battler, but she was always weaker. She used to use it as an excuse. That's why she had no friends at school. That's why she never found a partner. That's why she never held down a job for long. Always the victim, you see. Ultimately, that's why she stayed in Baytara. And, you know, I could have taken her out of there just before the virus struck. Just for once, things went my way. I came into some money, bought a house out on one of the ocean cities, promised myself I'd take care of her. And then she called. She had the sweats. By then, of course, we knew, she knew. She kept the vid-link open right the way through. Didn't spare me a thing. I sat and watched it. The vomiting, the sores. I watched the flesh on her face melt in front of me. She died alone. That's why I'm here, C'Rizz. That's why I believe in Major Koth. And that's why I'll have your friends shot before I'll let them escape.
It can't be blood.
Well, it certainly looks like it.
It probably isn't even red. In this half-light it just looks an admittedly rather nasty shade of claret.
Distant voices.
Sounds like they're getting closer. Come on, we'd better keep moving.
Janto? Have you still got a trace on them? We're in auburn sector three.
[OC]: They're about twenty to thirty spans ahead of you. Make sure you keep branching left.
They've been here. There are footprints in the soil.
[OC]: Quillian, the tunnel they're in, it's taking them to a dead end. You should be able to pin them down.
Running boots.
Well, now what do we do? Looks like we've come to the end of the road.
Not quite. There's a small pool down there. I wonder if this red water's safe?
You really do think it's claret?
No, but it might be the only chance we've got.
Splash.
Feels all right, but I can't really tell.
Big splash.
You want me to dive into that? It's only just about big enough to sit in.
Looks can be deceptive.
How do you know it even leads anywhere?
I don't. Logically, it should.
We could always surrender.
What?
Why are we running? These people, I don't think they're evil. Misguided, maybe, but I think we can talk with them.
Hey, don't start with this again. They brainwashed an experienced soldier into executing his commanding officer in front of you. Does that strike you as reasonable behaviour?
You don't know they did that.
Listen.
Distant angry voices.
Do they sound like they just want to have a cosy chat?
But what about C'Rizz?
We shall come back for him, I promise, but we won't be able to help him locked up in their brig again.
Well, if you're sure.
Water splashes.
You ready?
Not at all.
Excellent. Take a deep breath, Charley, and stay close to me.
Two big splashes.
That's funny.
What is?
They've disappeared off the scanner, virtually simultaneously.
Are they dead?
No. No, I still get a residual reading. They must be shielding themselves somehow.
Gasping and coughing in water.
Charley, you all right?
Over here.
Hang on, I'll come over to you.
There's no land down here. We're no better off than we were before.
That rock in the middle, can you see it?
Yes.
Head for it.
Oh, what's that? I just swam into something. Urgh, it stinks.
What is it?
I don't know. It's rotting meat, like a dead animal or something. Urgh, there's quite a few of them around me.
Help me to get one. Grab the end. That's it. Let's try to get it up onto that rock.
We've come to the end of the tunnel. There's no sign of them, Janto.
[OC]: I've picked up their traces again. They're in a cavern adjacent to you. I've got it as a dead zone on the maps because there's no way into it.
Well, you've got it wrong, then. There must be a way in.
I think I can guess how they did it.
Give me your hand, Charley. That's it. Now, climb up. You okay?
Oh, that was disgusting. Not only does it look like blood, it feels like oil and tastes like sh
Charley! Well, it's not the Mediterranean, I grant you, but at least we got away from our friends back there.
Doctor, what is this thing? It looks like it should be hanging from a hook in a butcher's shop.
I'm not sure, but I hope it's not bait for something that lives here.
Now you tell me.
Look at the water. There must be twenty or thirty of them floating in there.
How did they get in here?
Good question. Perhaps there's more openings under the water. I wish I knew what they were, though.
When I was a child, my grandmother used to take me to a local artist once a year. She liked having portraits of us all. He always had a basic wooden model to work from, of a human torso.
You know, I think you could be right.
[OC]: The limbs haven't so much been removed as eroded away. These skinned hunks of meat, I think they were people once.
He senses the truth of things, but cannot see the detail.
2: What should we do with him?
Watch him. See how he responds.
And then we shall break down his resistance.
You have made your decision, then?
He is our choice. He is a Time Lord. He is not of this planet. He is not of this universe.
2: Why does he look smaller from outside his head?
Splash, gasp.
Doctor, look. They've followed us in.
You two, remain where you are.
Well, it's not like we're going anywhere.
You all right, Bryn?
(coughs) I'm fine. Secure the prisoners. I'll catch you up.
Doctor, now what do we do?
I don't know. We don't exactly have options.
He is concerned about the female.
He cares for her. He is trapped, yet still believes he will escape.
2: His mind is exquisite, constantly turning.
He is accustomed to victory.
We must teach him otherwise. He must learn that nothing is as it appears. Focus your thoughts.
You two seem pretty keen to leave. I take it you're not the real Dorin.
Considering we've been abducted, taken underground and locked up against our will, why should I tell you anything?
Tell me who you are or I'll end this now.
What's happening to the water? Oh!
Bryn?
Charley, get back from the edge.
Bryn is screaming.
Bryn, get yourself up here.
He's burning up!
The water, it's as if it's become acid!
The screaming stops.
You did this. I knew it. A bioweapon of some sort.
Don't be ridiculous. You saw what happened. We need to pool our resources, not argue.
Shut up!
Mmmph!
Let her go.
You, Dorin, or whoever you are. Jump. Jump or I'll push her in.
Doctor!
I warned you.
Charley screams. Splash!

BRYN: Er, there was a mission.
DOCTOR: That's it, concentrate.
KOTH: Bryn, you have been given a direct order.
JANTO: Major, wait. This man. I believe he is Dorin, a scientific strategist from home.
VAYLA: It's true, Major. We've been expecting Dorin and his aide for days now.
KOTH: Has anybody actually asked him? Well? Is that what you are? A scientific strategist?
DOCTOR: Some might say so.
KOTH: Really? All right, Bryn, you can stop flapping now. Vayla. Please endeavour to authenticate our guest's identity.
VAYLA: Yes, sir.
KOTH: But keep him and his friend under lock and key until you do. We can always reconvene if you can't.
VAYLA: Sir.
KOTH: Keep me informed.
DOCTOR: It seems I owe you my life.
VAYLA: You're in luck. It's not every day Janto starts leaping in front of loaded guns.
DOCTOR: Are public executions the norm around here?
JANTO: No, they are not. What the hell was all that about, Vayla?
VAYLA: That's enough.
JANTO: Don't tell me you condone it. I know you too well.
VAYLA: I said, enough, Janto.
DOCTOR: I really think Bryn needs some help. I don't think he's quite himself.
VAYLA: He'll be looked after. But I should be more concerned about your own situation. We still have to verify your identity. And trust me, if you're not Dorin, then what happened to your friend will seem an act of mercy by comparison.
QUILLIAN: Our living quarters are a bit spartan, I'm afraid. You do sleep on a bed?
C'RIZZ: Not usually, but this will do.
QUILLIAN: Bryn, are you okay?
BRYN: That woman I killed
QUILLIAN: Was a spy and an enemy agent. It's one of the Major's gifts, routing out infiltrators.
BRYN: She seemed familiar.
C'RIZZ: Her name was Tysus.
BRYN: Oh. It means nothing to me. But then there's you. Have we met before?
C'RIZZ: On the surface, remember?
QUILLIAN: Don't worry. New recruits often suffer a bit of disorientation. Living this far underground takes a bit of getting used to. Execution was probably asking a little bit too much too soon.
BRYN: Are you with someone? That man with Tysus?
C'RIZZ: Yes, we met earlier in the jungle. By the crashed skimmer?
QUILLIAN: Like I said, it's quite natural. You'll adapt.
C'RIZZ: How long did it take you?
QUILLIAN: I can't really remember now. Your senses get affected too. Funny thing is, when we do finally leave these caves, I'll miss them. They've been a safe haven for us.
C'RIZZ: How long have you been down here?
QUILLIAN: Long enough. Meanwhile, we need to get you both settled in. I'll get Janto to give you the guided tour.
VAYLA: We'll try and clear this up as quickly as possible. Meanwhile, I suggest you rest.
DOCTOR: In a prison cell.
VAYLA: For the moment.
CHARLEY: What exactly have I done, by the way?
VAYLA: As you clearly know one another, I'm hardly going to let you have the run of the camp. And I wouldn't try anything stupid. This defence screen contains energies concentrated enough to reduce you to pulp.
DOCTOR: Don't we even get a cup of tea?
CHARLEY: Doctor, what happened back there?
DOCTOR: I'm not entirely sure I Know. Only what we saw. A man coldbloodedly shoot his
DOCTOR: commanding officer in the head.
CHARLEY: Was he a traitor all along, then?
DOCTOR: He might have been, but I don't think so. There was no betrayal about him, no glee, no sorrow, nothing. No emotion at all. He hardly seemed aware of what he was doing. If I had to hazard a guess, I'd say some form of mental control.
CHARLEY: And three guesses who's responsible.
DOCTOR: I wouldn't rush to conclusions just yet, but there's certainly something in these caves capable of exerting a telepathic influence. I felt it myself when I entered them.
CHARLEY: Well, I didn't feel anything. But then I'm not an all-powerful Time Lord.
DOCTOR: It's not just that. You know, I've known rebels in my time, helped overthrow the odd regime.
CHARLEY: Show-off.
DOCTOR: But there's a quality they've all had in common. A hunger, a desire, if you like. But that lot back there, they're different. I don't know what it is, but there's a stench about them, Charley.
C'RIZZ: What are they doing?
JANTO: Practicing scenarios. Our enemies are well organised and well hidden. They're spread on many different worlds, even out in space, so we try and prepare for every possibility.
VAYLA: Janto, where's Bryn?
JANTO: Resting. He needs a while to settle in. Perhaps asking him to put a laser bolt through someone's skull wasn't the best way of welcoming him.
VAYLA: All right, you've made your point.
JANTO: I'm just giving C'Rizz the guided tour, Commander.
VAYLA: You've had no problems acclimatising, then.
C'RIZZ: None so far.
VAYLA: You know, I'm familiar with over forty different alien species in this region of space, and yet you are something completely new to me. Care to shed some light?
C'RIZZ: I'm Eutermesan.
VAYLA: And I'm the Whore Queen Babayesh. What's a Eutermesan?
JANTO: What's it look like.
VAYLA: My patience isn't infinite, Janto. Well?
C'RIZZ: There really is no mystery. I'd be happy to sit and tell you all about my people.
VAYLA: Excellent. And while you're at it, perhaps you'd care to explain how and why you're here. No Ondrokkan agent that's come near to this camp has escaped to tell the tale. This location is one of the most sought after secrets in the sector, and yet here you are.
C'RIZZ: I'm not an agent of your government.
VAYLA: You know, there's a very simple way to establish the truth.
JANTO: Vayla? You can't.
VAYLA: Janto, I've taken about as much insubordination from you as I'm going to today. Don't push me. Well, C'Rizz. How's about we settle this for once and for all?
C'RIZZ: I have nothing to hide.
VAYLA: Good. Oh, and did I mention this could be unpleasant?
QUILLIAN: Attention, attention. This is Central Command to all sectors. As of midnight tonight, food rations will be decreased by ten percent for one cycle, after which the situation will be reviewed. Your cooperation is appreciated.
KOTH: Morale will dip.
QUILLIAN: Major. I didn't hear you come in.
KOTH: But you must ensure they hold their nerve. We are so close now.
QUILLIAN: Everyone is behind you, sir. Morale will hold. But if you'll allow me, it's hard to maintain a tight infrastructure when people keep getting transferred. We lost three more last month. They went to join the others at North Camp, but we've not heard from them since. If we ran a tighter ship
KOTH: You have a problem with Commander Vayla?
QUILLIAN: Some organisational issues could be better maintained.
KOTH: How diligent of you, Sub-Commander. Think you could handle it better, do you?
QUILLIAN: It's just that we're not replacing the people who move on.
KOTH: Then it is essential that we have new recruits. Utilise our agents in the field. The Ondrokkan people are scared and lost. They see us as their salvation. Prompt them. Encourage them to leave the planet and head towards us. Bring them to me. They are our life blood, Quillian.
VAYLA: Roll up your sleeve.
C'RIZZ: A truth serum?
VAYLA: A rather simplistic way of putting it.
JANTO: Vayla, for your own sake, don't do this.
VAYLA: Look at him. Haven't you noticed?
JANTO: What?
VAYLA: His colour. It's changed since he arrived. Darker, greyer.
C'RIZZ: My skin adapts to its environment. It's merely adjusting to the darkness of these caverns.
VAYLA: You see? You see how much we don't know?
JANTO: But he's not exactly avoiding your questions. Why do this?
VAYLA: Because this one's different.
C'RIZZ: No, I'm not.
JANTO: Why stop at him? Why not pump it into the two in the holding cells while you're at it? Think about it. Think about what you're doing.
C'RIZZ: I said I'm not different. I'm a man. I may look different, but I am simply a man with the same principles, dignity, and self-respect as any of you.
VAYLA: I'm sorry. I have to know. Roll up your sleeve.
JANTO: Listen to him.
C'RIZZ: Is this what your army stands for? Execution and torture?
VAYLA: I won't ask again.
C'RIZZ: Is this what you stand for, Commander? Because I don't accept that.
VAYLA: Why?
C'RIZZ: Your eyes tell me so.
VAYLA: All right, C'Rizz. I'll take you at your word. But if you prove me wrong, I'll pull the trigger myself.
DOCTOR: It's funny. You can travel all over one universe, then turn up in another, and it's still all about opening locked doors. Who says there isn't a greater pattern at work?
CHARLEY: Doctor, what are you doing?
DOCTOR: I'm trying to get out, of course.
CHARLEY: And then where? Into the Tardis and off we go? Only, oh yes, we've lost the Tardis.
DOCTOR: Have we really, though? I have the strangest feeling about the old girl.
CHARLEY: Yes, but are your strange feelings going to get us anywhere? Why don't you just accept that we're not getting out of it.
DOCTOR: Charley, I don't fancy hanging around here until they find out they've got the wrong people. In case you hadn't noticed, they don't exactly lay on tea and fruitcake for visitors.
CHARLEY: I'd have thought you'd be interested in helping them.
DOCTOR: What?
CHARLEY: These rebels. They're fighting for something they believe in.
DOCTOR: How do you know what they're fighting for?
CHARLEY: That man who saved you.
DOCTOR: Janto.
CHARLEY: He helped me with my hand. He's not a murderer. You heard what he said. He was as horrified as we were.
DOCTOR: Trust me, Charley, there's nothing scarier than a well-meaning freedom fighter. They don't usually stop until there's

CHARLEY: Well, there's a simple way to find out.

DOCTOR: Just a little scout around, and then we'll try and find out where C'Rizz has got to.
CHARLEY: Your sixth sense isn't telling you the Tardis is just round the corner, is it?
DOCTOR: Sorry. Though oddly enough I can still feel her presence like a little voice nagging me at the back of my mind.

VAYLA: Have you got a lock on their traces?
QUILLIAN: They're the only two down here without comms badges. We've managed to isolate their patterns in auburn sector four.
VAYLA: Get after them, and take Bryn with you. They mustn't reach the surface. If you can't bring them back, shoot them down.
DOCTOR: Sounds like they've noticed our absence. I suggest we get moving.
CHARLEY: Yes, but where to?
DOCTOR: Can you hear water?
CHARLEY: Yes.
DOCTOR: Come on, that might be just what we need.
DOCTOR: Well, this is more like it, Charley. A stream. If we can trace it to the surface
CHARLEY: Doctor.
DOCTOR: If the water flow is being channelled through that far wall
CHARLEY: Look!
DOCTOR: Then I think the source might. What?
CHARLEY: The water. Look at it. Look at the colour. It's blood.
JANTO: Fantastic security, Vayla. Who forgot to lock the back door, then?
VAYLA: Not now, Janto. Can you track their patterns?
JANTO: Yes, I've got them. Ah, they've made some headway. They're just crossing into sector five now.
C'RIZZ: I heard the alarms. What happened?
